title: 103_hr4545
content: The "Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994" authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 1995 to 1998. It also introduces pilot projects for hours of service in the railroad industry. The "Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994" allows railroads and labor organizations to petition the Secretary of Transportation for a waiver of compliance with certain requirements for up to two years to establish pilot projects demonstrating alternative approaches to employee work hours. The "Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994" allows waivers for railroad safety regulations, with the possibility of extension for up to two years. The Secretary of Transportation must report to Congress on the effectiveness of pilot projects established under waivers, status of other waivers, and recommend legislative changes. The term 'directly affected covered service employees' refers to relevant employees. The "Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994" allows waivers for railroad safety regulations, with the possibility of extension for up to two years. The term 'affected covered service employees' means covered service employees to whom the terms of the waiver specifically apply. The Federal Railroad Safety Authorization Act of 1994 allows waivers for railroad safety regulations, with the possibility of extension for up to two years. Section 21303(a)(1) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include violations of waivers granted under section 21108. Section 20111(c) is amended to include violations of laws transferred to the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Transportation. Additionally, there is a provision for biennial federal railroad safety reporting. Section 20116 of title 49, United States Code is amended to require a biennial comprehensive report on the administration of railroad safety regulations. The report must include information on casualties by cause for the preceding two calendar years. The table of sections for chapter 201 is also updated to reflect this change. The Secretary must provide a report on railroad bridge displacement detection systems to the Senate and House committees within 18 months of this Act. Additionally, there will be a focus on track safety. SEC. 8. TRACK SAFETY. Amends Section 20142 of title 49, United States Code to update dates and include procedures for identifying internal rail defects. SEC. 9. RESIDENCE OF EMPLOYEES. The amendments made by section 7 of the Amtrak Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 1990 apply to all periods before and after enactment. Passed the House of Representatives on August 8, 1994.
